title: Pentecostals and the spiritual war against coronavirus in Africa
author: Benjamin Kirby; Josiah Taru; Tinashe Chimbidzikai
description: Framing the fight against coronavirus as a spiritual war may stem from a shared sense of discomfort about an adversary without discernible conscience; an impersonal demon.
cleaned_text: Since the emergence of [COVID-19](https://theconversation.com/africa/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=COVID-19&sort=relevancy&language=en&date=week&date_from=&date_to=), a number of [media commentators](https://www.ft.com/content/7c3a17c6-f130-4659-972f-0fe9ebc7102b) and [academics](https://www.theelephant.info/features/2020/03/23/religion-in-the-age-of-coronavirus/) have reflected on the " [spiritualisation](https://religiousmatters.nl/dealing-with-a-spiritual-virus-whither-the-prophetic/)" of the pandemic among responses in different African settings. There's been particular interest in the influence of prominent [Pentecostal](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Pentecostalism) pastors on public health messaging. Some have expressed concern about the possible consequences of their invocations of spiritual warfare. We've examined how [idioms](https://www.grammar-monster.com/glossary/idiom.htm) of (spiritual) warfare have been deployed in response to the coronavirus pandemic and wish to bring a broader perspective to recent debates about these dynamics. We consider examples from Tanzania and Zimbabwe, drawing on our ongoing research in these settings. Many Pentecostal Christians, in Africa as well as [other continents](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/apr/04/america-rightwing-christian-preachers-virus-hoax), portray the coronavirus as a " [spiritual force of evil](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ephesians+6%3A12&version=NRSV)" rather than as a biomedical disease. Through this lens, the world is presented as a [battleground](https://www.academia.edu/31074897/Occupying_the_Global_City_Spatial_Politics_and_Spiritual_Warfare_among_African_Pentecostals_in_Hong_Kong) between God and the agents of Satan. For those who enlist to "fight for Jesus", the most effective weapon is prayer. Spiritual warfare provides a [framework](https://www.biblestudytools.com/bible-study/topical-studies/spiritual-warfare-lesson-1-understanding-the-battle-11554631.html) for explaining and responding to both mundane and extraordinary events - from a cancelled flight to a global pandemic. But despite their close association with Pentecostals, these militarised idioms may also [resonate](https://brill.com/view/book/edcoll/9789004281875/B9789004281875-s008.xml) with other groups. The prophet In Zimbabwe, [Prophet Emmanuel Makandiwa](https://emmanuelmakandiwa.com/) has been [criticised](https://www.thezimbabwemail.com/zimbabwe/outrage-as-emmanuel-makandiwa-goes-blasphematory/) for reassuring his congregants that they will be "spared" from the virus. This will happen through prayer and the divine protection he mediates. "You will not die, because the Son is involved in what we are doing," he says, calling it the freedom that no medication can offer. This [declaration](https://www.zimeye.net/2020/04/06/watch-video-makandiwa-vows-he-will-never-take-coronavirus-vaccine/) epitomises a sense of Pentecostal "exceptionalism", embodied in the claim to be " [in this world but not of this world](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=John+17%3A16&version=NRSV)". It clearly risks instilling a level of complacency among his followers about the threat of the virus. It amplifies the possibility of [noncompliance](https://religioninpublic.com/2020/04/03/pentecostalism-public-health-and-covid-19-in-nigeria/) with government [safety measures](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-zimbabwe/zimbabwe-locks-down-to-fight-coronavirus-amid-economic-crisis-idUSKBN21H2DF). Prophet Makandiwa has also been accused of perpetuating [conspiracy theories](https://theconversation.com/uk/topics/the-anthill-podcast-27460). Drawing Biblical allusions to the " [mark of the beast](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Revelation+13%3A16-18&version=NRSV)", he has warned followers about "microchip" implants. These, he predicts, will accompany future vaccination campaigns. This claim has also been made by pastors [elsewhere](https://religioninpublic.com/2020/04/03/pentecostalism-public-health-and-covid-19-in-nigeria/) in the [African](http://www.daily-mail.co.zm/covid-19-fuels-5g-conspiracy-theories/) continent. In Uganda, steps have already been taken to [prosecute](https://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1517283/pastor-yiga-spend-seven-prison) pastors spreading misinformation. The president Efforts to "spiritualise" the virus have also been pursued by some African leaders. For example, Tanzanian President [John Pombe Magufuli](https://www.thecitizen.co.tz/news/PROFILE--John-Pombe-Joseph-Magufuli-/1840340-2927326-k4xewcz/index.html) described COVID-19 as a demon (shetani). Through it Satan seeks to " [destroy](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7r8T0Wx4sQI)" Tanzanian citizens. Despite the government promoting physical distancing, he declared that churches or mosques would not be closed because this is where God and "true healing" (uponyaji wa kweli) are found. Invoking the idiom of spiritual warfare, Magufuli explained that COVID-19 cannot survive in the Body of Jesus (and) will be burned away. [Commentators](https://mg.co.za/africa/2020-04-27-crisis-what-crisis-how-not-to-handle-a-pandemic/?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=Facebook#Echobox=1588004073) have observed that Magufuli is himself a Roman Catholic (albeit with Pentecostal [ties](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SqP_XHggKO4&feature=emb_title)). Yet few have acknowledged his implication that God can also be "found" in mosques, nor his [recommendation](https://kenyanbreaking.co.ke/others/chemsheni-mwarubaini-magufuli-tells-tanzanians/) that Tanzanians also embrace indigenous medicinal practices for protection. In a country where Christians don't constitute a clear religious majority, Magufuli invokes the rhetoric of spiritual warfare to articulate a sense of national religious identity. These invocations mostly adopt a rhetorical style reminiscent of Pentecostal pastors but maintain a broad, inclusive focus on God (Mungu). Tanzanians responded enthusiastically to Magufuli's [call for](https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/tanzanian-president-declares-3-days-national-prayer-help-defeat-coronavirus) citizens "of every faith" to participate in three days of national prayer. Many took to social media to circulate photos and [videos](https://twitter.com/MsigwaGerson/status/1251444039376920577?s=20) featuring the Tanzanian flag and words of prayer. Some perspective Yet a growing number of [commentators](https://africanarguments.org/2020/04/27/president-magufuli-covid-19-we-need-leadership-not-prayers/) have criticised Magufuli. As with Makandiwa, they argue that his use of spiritual warfare rhetoric generates a dangerous expectation of viral immunity. Some [commentators](https://africasacountry.com/2020/04/the-devil-coronavirus) have taken Magufuli's emphasis on prayer to be [emblematic](https://twitter.com/MsigwaPeter/status/1252894425124126720) of the government's perceived [failure](https://twitter.com/fatma_karume/status/1253583821116715009?s=20) to [adequately address](https://www.newframe.com/tanzanias-state-response-to-covid-19-under-fire/) the [pandemic](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-23/tanzanian-president-says-country-can-ill-afford-a-virus-lockdown). The government, say critics, has fallen prey to " [superstitious](https://twitter.com/ThatBoyKhalifax/status/1241789034231484425)" thinking. [Some](https://twitter.com/IanBabi/status/1252312358535471105?s=20) draw allusions to the use of water-based medicine in the [Maji Maji](https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/6df4/70fd66fbb5cd32e13802f54e4b91324504ad.pdf) rebellion against German colonial rule. As [others](https://africasacountry.com/2020/04/praying-through-the-pandemic) have [observed](https://africasacountry.com/2020/04/the-devil-coronavirus), the act of giving spiritual agency to the virus as a "personal demon" can also serve to downplay structural failures which have contributed to its spread. It [divests responsibility](https://www.academia.edu/39252346/Pentecostalism_economics_capitalism_putting_the_Protestant_Ethic_to_work) to both COVID-19 as a sentient "enemy" and citizens. There is a risk, however, that exaggerating the "idiosyncrasy" of the Tanzanian government's response to COVID-19 - and indeed that of Prophet Makandiwa - may perpetuate another myth of "exceptionalism". One which echoes colonial depictions of African populations as singularly "superstitious" and " [incurably religious](https://brill.com/view/journals/exch/32/2/article-p123_4.xml)". In truth, spiritual warfare idioms have been diversely invoked - and unevenly received - across the continent. They have [prompted](https://www.theelephant.info/features/2020/03/23/religion-in-the-age-of-coronavirus/) lively " [religion and science](https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/africaatlse/2020/04/20/covid19-religious-institutions-public-health-science-africa/)" debates. Moreover, the plausibility of spiritual warfare idioms should not be exclusively attributed to people's religious sensibilities. After all, "warfare" is the [signature trope](https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/in-defence-of-war-metaphors-in-the-covid-19-conflict-k8l08nngv) with which global political figures, health experts, and media commentators have framed COVID-19. Like Magufuli, world leaders like the all invoked warfare motifs against the single, identifiable "enemy". European governments have also been [accused](https://economicsociology.org/2020/04/24/herd-immunity-is-epidemiological-neoliberalism/) of using this framing to shift responsibility onto citizens as "combatants", whether for failing to adhere to physical distancing or for their biomedical frailty. Narratives of individuals heroically " [winning their war](https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/apr/07/horror-coronavirus-real-imaginary-war-britain)" against a decidedly personal demon are no less persuasive to some in Europe than to some in Africa. None of this is intended to take away from the ambivalent and sometimes plainly harmful effects of attempts to spiritualise the pandemic. Nor is it to imply that religiously informed strategies of communication and implementation are incompatible with more "temporal" methods. Religious groups like Pentecostal congregations may indeed constitute an important " [public health resource](https://religionanddiplomacy.org.uk/2020/03/30/covid-19-and-pentecostals-in-africa/)" when it comes to delivering [services](https://www.rug.nl/research/centre-for-religious-studies/religion-conflict-globalization/blog/wash-your-hands-and-be-washed-in-the-blood-of-the-lambpentecostalism-and-the-coronavirus-30-03-2020) and [messaging](https://www.rug.nl/research/centre-for-religious-studies/religion-conflict-globalization/blog/wash-your-hands-and-be-washed-in-the-blood-of-the-lambpentecostalism-and-the-coronavirus-30-03-2020). And they can cultivate a sense of hope and [mutual care](https://www.newframe.com/thoughts-on-the-planetary-an-interview-with-achille-mbembe/) in the face of uncertainty. Rather, we suggest as anthropologists and scholars of religion, this warfaring rhetoric might stem from a shared discomfort among Africans and Europeans alike at the prospect of an adversary without discernible self-will or conscience. An impersonal demon. As literary critic [Anders Engberg-Pederson](http://www.boundary2.org/2020/04/anders-engberg-pedersen-covid-19-and-war-as-metaphor/?fbclid=IwAR2HThyE2hfKiLUVNj9IaQPwL89uVyoJL1KG0FNFCWR8LeZBdb-a9EoBKMw) articulates it: We declare war on the virus, because we want it to be something that it is not.
